user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_close_:
```c
static int lfs_file_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    int err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);
#else
    int err = 0;
#endif

    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist*)file);

    // clean up memory
    if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }

    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_file_close_:
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated: the condition depends on a runtime field (file->cfg->buffer). The lfs_free call is reachable whenever file->cfg->buffer == NULL (for example, if a file was opened without a user buffer), so there is no unreachable code in this fragment. (Only if the project globally guarantees file->cfg->buffer is always non-NULL would the branch be provably unreachable, but no such invariant is shown here.)
